The spots remain for days to weeks and can leave postinflammatory pigmentation. Fleas and mites that live on cats and dogs are often responsible. Wear protective clothing and apply insect repellents to exposed skin to prevent insect bites when outdoors, Insecticides can be used to rid the house. Seek veterinary advice regarding infested animal. Apply topical corticosteroid cream, calamine, or menthol lotions and creams and oral antihistamines are used in severe itching.

It is a case of sebaceous cyst, a non-cancerous growth of sebaceous glands. Sebaceous cysts are usually found on the face and neck. They can be painful and may bleed. Seborrheic cysts are not cancerous, but they can be removed for cosmetic or pain-related reasons. Seborrheic cysts are caused by sebaceous glands clogging with sebum and dead skin cells. Seborrheic cysts can also be caused by hormonal changes, medications like birth control pills, and genetic disorders. Seborrheic cysts are not cancerous, but they can be removed for cosmetic or pain-related reasons. Seborrheic cysts are found on the face and neck. They can be painful and may bleed. This is most likely a case of dyshidrotic eczema of the genitalia. The dyshidrotic eczema is aggravated by atopic dermatitis, excessive sweating, and sun exposure. Avoid aggravating factors where possible. Wear cotton clothing and avoid synthetic fabrics. Use a mild soap for handwashing and apply a topical steroid twice daily for 2-4 weeks. If persistent, consider systemic steroids or immunosuppressives.

These are spider veins. They appear when the valves in your veins become weak or damaged. You are more likely to develop spider veins if you have a family history of the condition, sit or stand for long periods of time with your legs crossed or in a slouched position, and if your weight is significantly over 150 pounds. Wearing high-quality compression stockings can help prevent the development of spider veins and can also be used as a treatment option.

This is eczema. Itâ€™s a chronic inflammatory skin condition that happens when the skin barrier breaks down. It can happen after excessive handwashing, irritant exposure, or allergen exposure. It can also happen with frequent bathing, particularly with hot water. Avoid irritants and allergens. Use gentle over-the-counter cleansers. Use mild, synthetic detergent-based cleansers rather than traditional soaps due to risk of irritation. Use lukewarm water not hot water. Use a total of 15-20 minutes to wash your body. Avoid harsh scrubbing. Apply moisturizer. Use topical medications to reduce itching and inflammation, such as topical hydrocortisone cream. Take oral medications such as anti inflammatory medicines, antihistamines, or corticosteroids to reduce itchiness and swelling. Avoid scratching.

The mole is now red and maybe more pigment too. This could be due to inflammation following laseurasion or it could be a normal response to inflammation. You should keep an eye on it and if it persists or if you notice any new lesions then you should see your dermatologist.

These look like they could be ingrown hairs, but they're not. They're most likely seborrheic keratoses, which are harmless growths on the skin. You don't need to do anything unless, of course, they're painful. You can shave them, but that will probably cause a scar.
This looks like seborrheic dermatitis. I would recommend a topical steroid and regular moisturization.

This is likely to be a case of onychomycosis, a fungal infection of the nail. You were already predisposed to onychomycosis due to your nail being thick. You can treat with antifungal medication, both topical and oral. You can also use a combination of antifungal medication and a keratolytic (material to be applied on nail) to remove the thick nail and reduce the risk of recurrence.

It is a case of eczema due to dry skin (xerosis). Dryness is commonly seen in people with atopic dermatitis. People exposed to a dry environment may experience dry skin, for example, low humidity in desert climates or cool windy conditions, excessive air conditioning, direct heat from a fire or fan heater, excessive bathing, contact with soap, laundry detergents and solvents, inappropriate topical agents such as alcohol, frictional irritation from rough clothing or abrasives. Try to eliminate aggravating factors. Reduce the frequency of bathing, use a humidifier in winter and air conditioner in summer, compare having a short shower with a prolonged soak in a hot bath, ensure good hydration by drinking plenty of water, use lukewarm water not hot water, replace standard soap with a substitute such as a synthetic detergent cleanser, water-miscible emollient, bath oil, anti-pruritic tar oil, colloidal oatmeal etc., and apply an emollient liberally and often, particularly shortly after bathing, and when itchy. The drier the skin, the thicker this should be, especially on the hands. Apply emollients frequently and avoid irritants. Use topical steroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks and oral antihistamines if needed.

This is a case of fungal infection due to high humidity and sweat. You can get itchy feet due to fungal infection as well. Wear socks and shoes throughout the day. Let your feet air out. Apply a topical antifungal cream (e.g. Terbinafine) twice daily for 2-4 weeks. If resistant to treatment, consult your doctor to rule out a fungal infection of the scalp.

This is a case of fungal infection of the feet. The skin of the feet is a fertile environment for fungi. Moisture retention and the limited number of sweat glands on the feet make it easy for fungi to grow. People with diabetes are at higher risk of developing fungal infections of the feet because their blood sugar levels are higher, which means there is more sugar in their blood. This can damage the blood vessels in their feet. Feet that are poorly ventilated, such as those covered with shoes, are also a good environment for fungi to grow. You can get a fungal infection if you wear enclosed footwear, walk barefoot in a public area where many people walk around, such as a locker room or sauna. You can also get a fungal infection if your feet have become very sweaty while you were in a confined space with poor ventilation. Let your feet air out, wash your feet daily, change your socks regularly, alternate pairs of shoes, and protect your feet in public places. Apply topical antifungal cream (terbinafine or clotrimazole) twice daily for 2-4 weeks. If resistant to treatment, consult a dermatologist for prescribing oral antifungal.

It is a case of eczema due to dry skin (xerosis). Dryness is commonly seen in people with atopic dermatitis. People exposed to a dry environment may experience dry skin, for example, low humidity in desert climates or cool windy conditions, excessive air conditioning, direct heat from a fire or fan heater, excessive bathing, contact with soap, laundry detergents and solvents, inappropriate topical agents such as alcohol, frictional irritation from rough clothing or abrasives. Try to eliminate aggravating factors. Reduce the frequency of bathing, use a humidifier in winter and air conditioner in summer, compare having a short shower with a prolonged soak in a hot bath, ensure good hydration by drinking plenty of water, use lukewarm water not hot water, replace standard soap with a substitute such as a synthetic detergent cleanser, water-miscible emollient, bath oil, anti-pruritic tar oil, colloidal oatmeal etc., and apply an emollient liberally and often, particularly shortly after bathing, and when itchy. The drier the skin, the thicker this should be, especially on the hands. Apply emollients frequently and avoid irritants. Use topical steroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks and oral antihistamines if needed.

It is a case of fungal infection. The skin around the toe is very thick, which provides a good environment for the fungus to grow. You should keep the feet as dry as possible. Wash the feet daily and apply a topical antifungal. It is important to use the right antifungal, as some are more effective against fungal skin infections than others. It may take several months to several years, depending on how severe the infection is. In severe cases, where the infection has spread up the leg, the foot may need to be amputated.

It is a case of plantar eczema usually triggered or aggravated by dry skin, excessive sweating, or insect bites. It is important to keep the feet as dry as possible. This may require the use of bandages to prevent friction between the feet and shoes. A topical steroid cream will help to reduce the redness and itching. It will take a few weeks to a few months to heal completely.
This is a case of folliculitis due to ingrown hair. You can try the following home remedies:

This is likely a case of contact eczema due to dry skin (xerosis). Dryness is commonly seen in people with atopic dermatitis. People exposed to a dry environment may experience dry skin, for example low humidity in desert climates or cool windy conditions, excessive air conditioning, direct heat from a fire or fan heater, excessive bathing, contact with soap, laundry detergents and solvents, inappropriate topical agents such as alcohol, frictional irritation from rough clothing or abrasives. Try to eliminate aggravating factors. Reduce the frequency of bathing,  use a humidifier in winter and air conditioner in summer, compare having a short shower with a prolonged soak in a hot bath, ensure good hydration by drinking plenty of water, use lukewarm water not hot water, replace standard soap with a substitute such as a synthetic detergent cleanser, water-miscible emollient, bath oil, anti-pruritic tar oil, colloidal oatmeal etc., and apply an emollient liberally and often, particularly shortly after bathing, and when itchy. The drier the skin, the thicker this should be, especially on the hands. Apply emollients frequently and avoid irritants. Use topical steroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks and oral antihistamines if needed.

This is a case of eczema due to dry skin (xerosis), contact, allergy or atopic eczema. Dryness is commonly seen in people with atopic dermatitis. People exposed to a dry environment may experience dry skin. For example, low humidity in desert climates or cool windy conditions, excessive air conditioning, direct heat from a fire or fan heater, excessive bathing, contact with soap, laundry detergents and solvents, inappropriate topical agents such as alcohol, frictional irritation from rough clothing or abrasives. Try to eliminate aggravating factors. Reduce the frequency of bathing,  use a humidifier in winter and air conditioner in summer, compare having a short shower with a prolonged soak in a hot bath, ensure good hydration by drinking plenty of water, use lukewarm water not hot water, replace standard soap with a substitute such as a synthetic detergent cleanser, water-miscible emollient, bath oil, anti-pruritic tar oil, colloidal oatmeal etc., and apply an emollient liberally and often, particularly shortly after bathing, and when itchy. The drier the skin, the thicker this should be, especially on the hands. Apply emollients frequently and avoid irritants. Use topical steroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks and oral antihistamines if needed. If persistent, it is recommended to consult your dermatologist.
This looks like a nevus or mole only. It does not look like melanoma at all. If you are worried, you should see your doctor for a possible biopsy.

Most probably it is a case of angiofibroma, benign vascular neoplasm composed of dermal fibrous tissue and blood vessels. Angiofibromas are non-cancerous growths that develop in the skin. They are usually found on sun-damaged skin. Angiofibromas can sometimes bleed, especially when they are first diagnosed. There are many different types of angiofibromas, and some may be treated. The treatment of angiofibromas depends on the individual case and the appearance of the lesion. Some options include:

Medical excision: A dermatologist will make a single incision to remove the lesion. This is the most simple and straightforward procedure.

Dermoscopy: A dermatologist uses a dermoscope, a handheld instrument with a light source and a lens, to examine the lesion. This can help identify the type of lesion and guide treatment.

Shotgun excision: A dermatologist uses a needle gun to remove the lesion. This is the most powerful and precise procedure.

Dermoscopy and dermoscopic examination is an important part of the diagnosis of angiofibromas. It can help identify the type of lesion and guide treatment. There are many different types of angiofibromas, and some may be treated. The treatment of angiofibromas depends on the individual case and the appearance of the lesion. Some options include:
Medical excision: A dermatologist will make a single incision to remove the lesion. This is the most simple and straightforward procedure.

It is a case of onychomycosis, a common fungal infection of the nails. Onychomycosis is contagious and can be spread via contaminated objects such as towels or razors that have touched a fungal nail or on the feet while walking around in public places. It can also be spread via nail polish containing the fungus. Avoid sharing items that touch the feet. Wash your feet regularly and wear socks and shoes. This will help prevent the growth of the fungus on your feet. To treat onychomycosis, you can use topical antifungal medication such as terbinafine or clotrimazole. Oral antifungal medication is also available. Always finish your course of medication before wearing nail polish. This will help ensure that the fungus is killed.

This looks like it could be a spider angioma, a benign vascular skin lesion. However, if it is new, changing, or bleeding then it could also be a dermatofibroma which is a bit more dangerous and may require a biopsy to diagnose properly. If it is a dermatofibroma then it will require excision, but if it is a spider angioma then it will require only excision.

It looks like eczema. It could be contact or atopic eczema. I am adding a cream, to be applied twice daily for 2 weeks. You can take an antihistamine on a PRN basis. Moisturise it well. Avoid irritants.

This looks like a case of post-treatment hyperpigmentation. This occurs when a lesion (in this case a mole) is exposed to the sun and produces too much melanin (the pigment that gives skin its color). There are a few things you can do to help reduce the appearance of post-treatment hyperpigmentation:
- Always wear sunscreen: even on cloudy days, UV rays can damage your skin and cause hyperpigmentation. Look for a sunscreen with an SPF of at least 30 and apply it every day.
- Wear protective clothing: long sleeves, hats, and sunglasses can all help protect your skin from the sun.
- Use topical steroids: apply a topical steroid cream to the area once daily for a week then twice daily for a week, then once per day for a month, and then once per week for a month. This will help reduce the appearance of the hyperpigmentation.
- Use topical azelaic acid: this is a type of vitamin C that helps reduce the appearance of hyperpigmentation. You can use a cream, lotion, or spray containing azelaic acid. Apply it once daily for a month. If you have sensitive skin, you can try using an over-the-counter (OTC) hydrocortisone cream. Apply it twice daily for a week then once per day for a month.

This looks like it could be a folliculitis. It is a reaction to hair follicle irritant. The best treatment for this would be a topical antibiotic and a topical retinoid. You could also consider an oral antibiotic if it is severe.

This is most likely an allergic reaction to some hair product that the barber used. I am adding a lotion for faster healing to be applied twice daily for 2 weeks. Avoid any contact with hair products for now.
I need to know whether there is any history of trauma, and if it has increased in size. As of now, I need you to send a picture of the mole.
This is nodular acne. You can get laser treatment for it. Keep the area clean. Apply the cream twice daily for 2 weeks. You can take painkiller on an as needed basis.

This is a case of ingrown hairs. You can get ingrown hairs when short, curly hairs curve back into your skin instead of growing out. For many people, this happens when they shave, which is why ingrown hairs are frequently called â€śrazor bumps.â€ť Encourage use of disposable razors or cleaning electric shavers with alcohol based antiseptic solution regularly to prevent infection of the grooming tool. Shave at the end of your shower or immediately afterward. This softens the hairs, so theyâ€™re less likely to curl back into your skin. Before shaving, apply a pre-shave gel and apply a fragrance-free shaving cream. Shave in the direction that your hair grows and rinse with lukewarm water. Gently pat your skin dry with a clean towel; leave your skin a little damp, this helps your skin retain moisture and apply a moisturizer formulated for your skin type. Use topical antibiotics such as clindamycin, mupirocin, and fusidic acid, oral antibiotics such as flucloxacillin or doxycycline, chlorhexidine/neomycin cream for eradication of nasal carriage and topical hydrocortisone cream can be also tried.

Most probably it is a case of Verruca vulgaris, a common wart. A wart is a small, noncancerous growth of the skin. They are caused by a virus of the family human papillomavirus (HPV). If you cut or damage your skin in some way, it's easier for the virus to take hold. That's why people with chronic skin conditions, such as eczema, or who bite their nails or pick at hangnails are prone to getting warts. Warts are highly contagious and are mainly passed by direct skin contact, such as when you pick at your warts and then touch another area of your body. You can also spread them with things like towels or razors that have touched a wart on your body or on someone else's. Most warts are harmless, and you don't need to do anything unless, of course, they're painful or embarrassing. Over-the-counter gels, liquids, and pads with salicylic acid work by peeling away the dead skin cells of the wart to gradually dissolve it. For better results, soak the wart in warm water, then gently sand it with a disposable emery board before you apply the product. Be sure to use a new emery board each time. Be patient, it can take several months. If you have diabetes or a weakened immune system, you should have a doctor take a look before you treat a wart yourself. Cryotherapy, immunotherapy, laser treatment and topical cantharidin are good therapeutic options.

This is eczema. Use mild facewash, good moisturizer, and sunscreen. Apply steroid cream first twice daily for 2 weeks, then make it once and slowly taper over 2 months. Meanwhile, start with the cream you are already using at night.

It is a case of urticaria, a self limiting immunological reaction to drugs, food, bites of mosquitoes, fleas, bedbugs, and other insects. The spots remain for days to weeks and can leave postinflammatory pigmentation. Fleas and mites that live on cats and dogs are often responsible. Wear protective clothing and apply insect repellents to exposed skin to prevent insect bites when outdoors, Insecticides can be used to rid the house. Seek veterinary advice regarding infested animal. Apply topical corticosteroid cream, calamine, or menthol lotions and creams and oral antihistamines are used in severe itching.

This is a case of longitudinal melanonychia where the nail has a light to dark brown or black coloration due to the presence of melanocytes (nail cells) that also produce melan pigment. This is normal and does not usually require treatment. However, if there is thickened or opaque discoloration (such as yellow or brown) then it may be a sign of a fungal infection of the nail (fungal keratosis) and you should be seen in person for an evaluation and possible treatment.

A stye is a small, red bump that forms on the edge of your eyelid. Itâ€™s usually caused by an infection or inflammation of the glands that produce oil. Styes are common and usually pass in a few weeks. For more persistent or recurrent styes, you should discuss with your doctor to rule out a more serious condition.

It is a case of common wart. This noncancerous growth appears when your skin is infected with one of the many viruses of the human papillomavirus (HPV) family. If you cut or damage your skin in some way, it's easier for the virus to take hold. That's why people with chronic skin conditions, such as eczema, or who bite their nails or pick at hangnails are prone to getting warts. Warts are highly contagious and are mainly passed by direct skin contact, such as when you pick at your warts and then touch another area of your body. You can also spread them with things like towels or razors that have touched a wart on your body or on someone else's. Most warts are harmless, and you don't need to do anything unless, of course, they're painful or embarrassing. Over-the-counter gels, liquids, and pads with salicylic acid work by peeling away the dead skin cells of the wart to gradually dissolve it. For better results, soak the wart in warm water, then gently sand it with a disposable emery board before you apply the product. Be sure to use a new emery board each time. Be patient, it can take several months. If you have diabetes or a weakened immune system, you should have a doctor take a look before you treat a wart yourself. Cryotherapy, immunotherapy, laser treatment and topical cantharidin are good therapeutic options.

This is a case of ringworm infection which is a fungal infection. Ringworm thrives in warm, moist areas, so it's important to keep the area clean and dry. You're already doing that by washing the area daily and keeping it dry. Ringworm thrives on dead skin cells, so it's a good idea to exfoliate once a week. This will remove the dead skin cells that ringworm uses as food. There are many over-the-counter antifungal creams and liquids that you can apply to the skin to treat ringworm. It may take several months, but you should continue to apply the cream or take the medicine regularly until the ringworm is gone and you can see that it has been completely eradicated.

It is not normal to have lots of moles on your face. The mole on your face is called a nevus. A nevus is a small, brown, and flat skin growth that can appear anywhere on your body. Most nevus are harmless, but some can develop into skin cancer. If you have many nevus on your face or if any of them are changing, growing, or bleeding then you should be seen in person by a dermatologist. A dermatologist can evaluate your nevus and decide if it needs to be removed.

This is likely to be a form of allergic rhinitis. It is chronic. You can take antihistamines and use topical corticosteroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks. If it is not getting better or you are taking antihistamines daily for more than 2 weeks, you may need to do a blood test to check for allergies or a skin biopsy to rule out cancer.

This is a case of Dark Cirrus Keratosis (DKC), a common benign (noncancerous) skin growth. It is more common in older people, particularly those with fair skin. It does not usually cause any problems and does not require treatment. If desired for cosmetic reasons, cryotherapy, laser treatment, or topical retinoids can be used.

It is eczema. It is a common skin condition that causes dry and itchy patches of skin. Itâ€™s not contagious, but it is contagious when you have active eczema. It is triggered by things like allergies, irritants, medications, and weather changes. The main treatment for eczema is to avoid what triggers it. That means you need to know your trigger(s) so you can avoid them. Common triggers are:

Fabrics, such as wool, curly hair, and synthetic fibers, that are itchy
Foods like peanuts, dairy, and eggs, that trigger allergies
Chemicals, such as perfume, solvents, and cleaning products, that irritate the skin
Medications, such as topical steroids, that can cause inflammation
Weather changes, such as hot weather, sun exposure, and windy weather, that irritate the skin

Acne is the most common dermatological condition in teenagers and young adults. It is characterized by the inflammation of the hair follicles (pimples) and may leave behind scars if not treated properly. Acne is caused by hormonal and metabolic abnormalities, and it tends to recurrcey after a period of remission. Acne medications are broadly divided into two groups based on how they affect the oil glands:

Acyclic Acne Creams and Gels: These are used to treat acne without inflammation. They include benzoyl peroxide, salicylic acid, and antibiotics like clindamycin or erythromycin.

Treated Acne: This includes the pimples that have been treated and are now healing. You may need to continue using an acne medication for a few months to years to keep the acne under control.

The acne medicine you need depends on how severe your acne is. Mild acne that only has a few pimples that are healing can be treated with a topical acne cream or gel. More severe acne may require an oral antibiotic, a steroid cream or gel, or a combination of both.

This is a case of folliculitis, an inflammation of the hair follicles. It can be caused by bacteria, viruses, or fungi. The most common cause of folliculitis is a hair styling product called pomade. Pomade contains alcohol which burns the skin and dries it out, leading to a condition called xerosis. You are also at risk of folliculitis if you shave your head, cut your hair very short, or use a lot of styling products. To treat folliculitis, you should stop doing these things and avoid using any products that might irritate your skin, such as pomade. Wash your hair with a gentle shampoo and apply a good moisturizer to your scalp. You can take antibiotics to treat an infection associated with the folliculitis, but this is not common.

This is a case of eczema due to dry skin (xerosis). Dryness is commonly seen in people with atopic dermatitis. People exposed to a dry environment may experience dry skin, for example, low humidity in desert climates or cool windy conditions, excessive air conditioning, direct heat from a fire or fan heater, excessive bathing, contact with soap, laundry detergents and solvents, inappropriate topical agents such as alcohol, frictional irritation from rough clothing or abrasives. Try to eliminate aggravating factors. Reduce the frequency of bathing, use a humidifier in winter and air conditioner in summer, compare having a short shower with a prolonged soak in a hot bath, ensure good hydration by drinking plenty of water, use lukewarm water not hot water, replace standard soap with a substitute such as a synthetic detergent cleanser, water-miscible emollient, bath oil, anti-pruritic tar oil, colloidal oatmeal etc., and apply an emollient liberally and often, particularly shortly after bathing, and when itchy. The drier the skin, the thicker this should be, especially on the hands. Apply emollients frequently and avoid irritants. Use topical steroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks and oral antihistamines if needed.

It is a case of melanoma in situ, which means the melanoma cells are only in the deeper layers of the skin. This is considered low-risk melanoma and does not require treatment. However, if you have already removed a mole and it was melanoma, then you need to remove it again because melanoma is cancer.
It is a case of eczema due to cold weather. Apply moisturizer. Wear gloves. I am adding a cream for same to be applied twice daily for 2 weeks. Avoid contact with any irritant.

I need a few answers- is there any history of trauma, infection, or medication? Have you been on treatment for any other problem? These are some general questions. As of now, I need to know- is it itchy? Have you been using any lotions or creams? Please add any other relevant information.

This is a case of nasal eczema or allergic nasal dermatosis. It is a common condition that is triggered in allergic individuals upon contact with an irritant or an allergen. Common allergens include pollen, mold, dust mites, pet dander, and certain foods. It is important to identify the trigger(s) in order to avoid them. Treatment of nasal eczema usually results in a significant improvement in symptoms. The most important treatment of all is to avoid the trigger(s). Use a humidifier in the winter and air conditioner in the summer to control allergens in the air. Wash your bedding and clothes regularly to remove allergens. Use a hypoallergenic pillowcase. Avoid using feather pillows. Wash pillowcases often. Use a topical steroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks and oral antihistamines if needed. If resistant to treatment, consult your doctor to rule out nasal polyps.

This is most likely a case of post-workout inflammation or vasodilation. This occurs when the blood vessels in the skin expand, causing the skin to look red and feel warm. This typically resolves within 30 minutes to an hour, but may persist for several days or weeks depending on the cause. If it is related to a dermatitis (eg, contact dermatitis, urticaria, or eczema) then it may take several months to resolve with the use of topical medications and lifestyle changes. If it is related to a dermatofibroma, then it may require a laser treatment.

This is most likely eczema. The areas around the hair follicles are particularly prone to become inflamed. I am adding a cream to be applied twice daily for 2 weeks. Apply moisturiser and use a mild soap. Avoid deodorant and friction from clothes.
This looks like a cyst. You need to see a doctor for surgical excision. Donâ€™t move an inch. I am adding a cream for faster healing to be applied twice daily for 2 weeks. Avoid friction.
Most probably it is a case of nevus or mole. Since it's now red and there are some borders, it seems like a case of inflammatory nevus or eczema. You can get it removed.

This is a case of telangiectasia, a benign vascular skin lesion that occurs when the blood vessels in the skin become dilated (widened). Telangiectasia is often described as a form of cosmetic vascular disease. It is most common in fair-skinned older women, but can occur in anyone. Telangiectasia does not cause symptoms in everyone, and some people may have only mild dilated blood vessels. Symptoms of telangiectasia may include persistent facial redness, known as flush, and telangiectasia-related telangiectasia pigment change. Telangiectasia is usually diagnosed clinically and investigation is not necessary for the majority of lesions. Telangiectasia is usually treated with lasers, electrical heat, or by topical medications containing retinoids or steroids.

This is most likely related to the itchiness of the area. It could be a fungal infection of the skin if it was itchy first. If it is itchy now and you have been scratching it for 3 days, then it is most likely related to the itchiness and you should try to stop scratching. If it is still itchy after that then it could be related to a fungal infection and you should see your doctor. If it is still itchy after that then it could be related to a skin barrier injury and you should see your doctor. If it is still itchy after that then it could be related to a secondary infection and you should see your doctor.

Most probably it is a case of chalazion. A chalazion is a small, noncancerous growth of blood vessels that forms in your skin. They usually begin to form in your skin when it ischy. You are more likely to get a chalazion if you scratch your skin too much. Chalazions donâ€™t usually cause any permanent damage to your skin, and most of them go away on their own. If a chalazion is painful or embarrassing, you can try the following treatments to help it go away faster:

Most probably these are blood spots due to some underlying trauma or injury. They can also be a result of some medication. You donâ€™t need to do anything unless they are very prominent. But if they are new or increasing in number then you should see your doctor for a possible biopsy.
This is eczema. Avoid irritants. Use mild soap anf apply moisturiser. Apply topical steroid twice daily for 2 weeks. If it still persists then systemic steroids might be required.
This is a viral infection known as molluscum contagiosum. It requires removal. This is communicable. Avoid touching to prevent spread to other body parts and to others.

This is a case of solar lentigo, a harmless condition that occurs when skin cells are damaged by ultraviolet (UV) radiation from the sun. People with solar lentigo have uneven pigmentation of their skin, with patches that are lighter and darker than the rest of their body. Solar lentigo is most common in people with fair skin who spend a lot of time in the sun. It can also occur in people with darker skin who have fair solar lentigo. Solar lentigo has nothing to do with race or nationality. It is not a form of skin cancer. It does not require treatment. People with solar lentigo may choose to treat it with topical steroids and regular use of sun protection to prevent further damage to the skin.

This is likely related to the nail bed. You can try topical treatments like topical retinoids, topical antibiotics, or topical antifungals. Oral antibiotics like doxycycline, flucloxacillin, and chlorhexidine/neomycin may be used in severe cases. Topical retinoids, including tretinoin, may also be used.

I need a few answers- is there any history of trauma or any infection? Have you been on medication for any other condition? We need to perform a handheld microscopic examination of the lesion and send it for histopathology examination. Meanwhile I am adding a cream- to be applied twice daily for 10 days.

This is most likely related to a spider angioma, a non-cancerous blood vessel growth. They can also be related to a skin tag, but are more likely to be a skin tag if they have been there for a while. You can treat with a topical steroid and a regular moisturizer. If they are new or changing then it may require a biopsy to be removed.

It is a case of eczema due to dry skin (xerosis). Dryness is commonly seen in people with atopic dermatitis. People exposed to a dry environment may experience dry skin, for example, low humidity in desert climates or cool windy conditions, excessive air conditioning, direct heat from a fire or fan heater, excessive bathing, contact with soap, laundry detergents and solvents, inappropriate topical agents such as alcohol, frictional irritation from rough clothing or abrasives. Try to eliminate aggravating factors. Reduce the frequency of bathing, use a humidifier in winter and air conditioner in summer, compare having a short shower with a prolonged soak in a hot bath, ensure good hydration by drinking plenty of water, use lukewarm water not hot water, replace standard soap with a substitute such as a synthetic detergent cleanser, water-miscible emollient, bath oil, anti-pruritic tar oil, colloidal oatmeal etc., and apply an emollient liberally and often, particularly shortly after bathing, and when itchy. The drier the skin, the thicker this should be, especially on the hands. Apply emollients frequently and avoid irritants. Use topical steroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks and oral antihistamines if needed.

I need to know whether there is any history of trauma or any irritant application. This looks like a mole only. You need to get it checked by an expert for confirmation and if it is benign you can observe it. If it is malignant, you need to get it removed.

This is lip dryness. Get your hemoglobin and vitamin B12 levels checked. Apply moisturizer. I am adding a cream for faster healing to be applied twice daily for 2 weeks. Avoid lip color, irritants, and tongue licking. Use white colored toothpaste.
This is a viral infection known as molluscum contagiosum. It requires removal. This is communicable. Avoid touching this lesion to prevent spread to other body parts and to others.

This is a case of alopecia areata. It is a type of autoimmune disorder. Stress can trigger it. So try to reduce stress. Take multivitamins once daily. Apply moisturizer. Use sun protection. Avoid harsh hair products. Avoid trauma.

It is a case of telangiectasia, a common benign vascular skin lesion. Telangiectasia are small blood vessels that have dilated or widened. They are most common on the nose, cheeks, and chin. Telangiectasia are not dangerous in themselves, but they can be a sign of underlying vascular disease. For example, telangiectasia may be a sign of deep vein thrombosis, in which case you may need a blood thinner to prevent a blood clot from becoming blocked in a deep vein. Telangiectasia may also be a sign of rosacea, a chronic inflammatory skin condition that usually begins between the age of 30â€“60 years. Rosacea is more common in women than in men. It is not contagious. Symptoms of rosacea can flare up if you are stressed, anxious, or hot. Use gentle or sensitive skin moisturizers throughout the day when you have a mild to moderate case of rosacea. Apply moisturizer when your skin is damp after a bath or shower. This will help your skin retain moisture throughout the day. Apply topical medications to your skin like topical azelaic acid, topical retinoids, or topical steroids. Take oral medications like antihistamines, beta-blockers, or vasodilators to reduce the redness and swelling associated with rosacea. Laser therapy is also an option. Laser therapy can be used to shrink small telangiectasia and improve the appearance of your skin.

This is eczema. It is very common in children. Use mild soap and moisturizer at regular intervals. I am adding a cream for faster healing to be applied twice daily for 2 weeks. Always make her wear cotton underneath. Avoid perfume and dyes.
This looks like eczema only. Apply moisturizer and sunscreen. Apply the cream which I have added twice daily for 2 weeks. Take antihistamine on an SOS basis.

This is very likely athlete's foot (tinea pedis). It is a fungal infection that usually begins between the toes. It commonly occurs in people whose feet have become very sweaty while confined within tight-fitting shoes. The condition is contagious and can be spread via contaminated floors, towels, or clothing. You are at higher risk of athlete's foot if you frequently wear enclosed footwear, sweat heavily, share mats, rugs, bed linens, clothes, or shoes with someone who has a fungal infection, walk barefoot in public areas where the infection can spread, such as locker rooms, saunas, swimming pools, communal baths and showers. Let your feet air out, wash your feet daily, change your socks regularly, alternate pairs of shoes, and protect your feet in public places. Apply topical antifungal cream (terbinafine or clotrimazole) twice daily for two to four weeks. If resistant to tretmant, consult a dermatologist for prescribing oral antifungal.

It is a case of nevus or mole. It is a benign (non-cancerous) growth of skin cells. They can be removed for cosmetic reasons, if they are affecting your vision, or if they are causing some other problem.

This is a case of longitudinal melanonychia, where the skin of the fingers becomes dark due to increased melanin production. It is mostly seen in people of Asian, Black, and Latin descent. It can occur in individuals with hyperpigmentation or melanodermatosis, or it can be a benign condition associated with increased melanin production. It can also be a sign of a skin cancer depending on the context. It is important to rule out any skin cancer before considering treatment for melanonychia. Treatment options include laser therapy, chemical peeling, and topical steroids.

This looks like eczema. It is not eczema and not ringworm. I need you to stop scratching. Scratching will only make it better for a little while and then it will get better again or it will get worse. I am adding a cream to be applied twice daily for 2 weeks. You can take an antihistamine on a PRN basis. Donâ€™t scratch.

It is a case of Pityriasis versicolor, a common yeast infection of the skin, in which flaky discolored patches appear on the chest and back. Pityriasis versicolor is more common in hot, humid climates than in cool, dry climates. It often affects people who perspire heavily. It may clear in the winter months and recur each summer. Although it is not considered infectious in the conventional sense, pityriasis versicolor sometimes affects more than one member of a family. Mild pityriasis versicolor is treated with topical antifungal agents. Selenium sulfide shampoo, Topical azole cream/shampoo (econazole, ketoconazole), Terbinafine gel. The medicine should be applied widely to the skin from the jawline down and left on the skin for 5-15 minutes before rinsing off in the shower. This should be done daily for one week then weekly for one month. Oral antifungal agents, itraconazole and fluconazole, are used to treat pityriasis versicolor when extensive or if topical agents have failed. Vigorous exercise an hour after taking the medication may help sweat it onto the skin surface, where it can effectively eradicate the yeast. Bathing should be avoided for a few hours. A few days' treatment will clear many cases of pityriasis long term, or at least for several months. Reapplication of a topical treatment such as selenium sulfide shampoo every month once the rash has cleared will usually prevent recurrence.

People exposed to a dry environment may experience dry skin, for example, low humidity in desert climates or cool windy conditions, excessive air conditioning, direct heat from a fire or fan heater, excessive bathing, contact with soap, laundry detergents and solvents, inappropriate topical agents such as alcohol, frictional irritation from rough clothing or abrasives. Use topical steroid cream twice daily for 2-4 weeks and oral antihistamines if needed.
